bioghist.p: Thomas Leiper (1745-1825) was born in Scotland and immigrated to Maryland in 1763. In 1765, he moved to Philadelphia and began a tobacco storage and export business. In 1780, he purchased several quarries. He amassed a large fortune, and contributed to improvements in Philadelphia, and in Delaware County, where he made his home. He was one of the founders of the first troop of city light horse, and served with them as Lieutenant during the Revolution in the battles of Trenton, Brandywine, and Germantown. He was a staunch democrat and participated in town meetings, and was a member, and eventually, president of the city council. He was also the director of the Banks of Philadelphia and the United States, and constructed the first permanent tramway in America.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of business volumes of Thomas Leiper and his descendants. These volumes record the activities of Thomas Leiper & Sons, Tobacconists, several quarries, a lumber yard and stable, and the Caldwell and Crosby estates. The volumes also record Leiperâ€™s purchase and sale of real estate. Volumes include: ledgers, account books, daybooks, letterbooks, order books, cash books, wage books, and receipt books.
